fields.description:
h1. Symptoms
Users can enable and disable nested groups support for Delegated Directories in applications that embed Crowd 2.6.0 (plugin version 1.6.0). The setting is persisted, because subsequent updates retain the value. However, when a user authenticates successfully, the group-to-group memberships are not copied to the database, and therefore not taken into account.

h1. Steps to reproduce
# Set up an LDAP directory (e.g., OpenLDAP) with two groups (group1 and group2). Make group1 a parent of group2. Create a user who is a member of group2 but not of group1.
# Create a Delegated Directory in Confluence 5.0-beta4 (which embeds Crowd 2.6.0). Enable "nested groups", "copy user details" and "copy group details".
# Log out from Confluence. Log in again using the credentials of the LDAP user created in step 1. Authentication should succeed.
# Go to group browser to see a list of all groups.

h1. Expected result
The list should contain "group1", since the user is an indirect member, and therefore, the group details should have been copied when he authenticated. Moreover, by clicking in "group1" it should be possible to see that it has "group2" as its member.

h1. Actual result
"group1" does not appear on the list.

h1. Notes
The issue cannot be reproduced in standalone Crowd because of a side-effect of CWD-3137. However, it has been verified in a feature branch of standalone Crowd with the fix for CWD-3137 in it.
fields.summary: 'Nested groups' setting is ignored by delegated authentication directories

fields.description:
It would be nice to have a text summary for Applications and Directories that Crowd admins can easily copy/paste or downloaded as a file to send to Support.

Ideally it would capture:
* Application configurations (the stuff in cwd_application* tables)
* Directory configurations (the stuff in cwd_directory* tables)
* How applications are linked to directories (the stuff in cwd_app_dir* tables)
fields.summary: Add a "Application/Directory Configuration Summary" inside the Crowd UI

fields.description: The first synchronisation will take longer than other times. For an upgrade to Embedded Crowd from a pre-Embedded application it may be the longest part of the upgrade. Log something at the start of synchronising users to indicate what's happening.
fields.summary: Log when synchronisation appears to be running against an empty local directory

fields.description:
One of the biggest problems we see in Crowd is that it's too easy to sync an entire LDAP tree, and difficult to restrict it without having a visual guide.

It'd be awesome if we could have a visual description of what DN's are being synced, and then a one click way of enabling/restricting them. Even better would be if that auto-created an LDAP filter to save users from writing them themselves.
fields.summary: Visual Display/Auto-Filter Feature

fields.description:
PreConditions:

open browser - FireFox/18.0.2
run debugger -FireBug/1.11.1

Step to reproduce:

1) Open the site url: www.noviysvit.dp.ua 
2) In the left menu «Каталог продукции» to select the link «Душевые  кабины»- «Гидромассажные боксы»
3) From the list, choose the link «Гидромассажный бокс НХ=416е| HX-417e» 
4) The right of the page «Гидромассажный бокс НХ=416е| HX-417e» click on the «Добавить в корзину»
5) Run FireBuge
6) Click FireBuge select «Щелкните на элементе страницы для анализа»
7) On the page, moving cursor "«Количество» and click the left-Prince. mouse 
8) In the line of the selected element tag « Количество», maxlength = 3 change to maxlength = 10 
9) Enter in the table of elements « Количество», '1000 'press Enter 
10) Click «Добавить товар в корзину»
11) Click «Продолжить оформления покупки»
12) Fill in the field «ФИО» - РДВ, «Моб.телефон»- +38 (093) 033-33-33, «Адрес доставки»  - ул.Попуас 1
13) Click «Оформить»

Actual result: 

Order is executed.

Expected result:

Order can not be executed. Error in database.
fields.summary: Checking the number of products in the database

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a directory to Crowd
# Replace one of the required attributes on the Configuration page with a " " character
# Save the page
#- Expected result - this would fail
#- Actual result - the page saves successfully
# Attempt to sync however, and you will see errors like this:
{code}
2013-02-06 11:40:13,680 http-8095-11 FATAL [springframework.ldap.control.AbstractRequestControlDirContextProcessor] No matching response control found for paged results - looking for 'class javax.naming.ldap.PagedResultsResponseControl
2013-02-06 11:40:13,680 http-8095-11 ERROR [console.action.principal.BrowsePrincipals] org.springframework.ldap.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; remaining name 'OU=Users,DC=company,DC=com,DC=au'
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: org.springframework.ldap.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; remaining name 'OU=Users,DC=company,DC=com,DC=au'
...
Caused by: org.springframework.ldap.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; remaining name 'OU=Users,DC=company,DC=com,DC=au'
...
Caused by: javax.naming.directory.InvalidSearchFilterException: invalid attribute description; remaining name 'OU=Users,DC=company,DC=com,DC=au'
{code}
fields.summary: It is possible to save a space (" ") character in place of a required configuration item

fields.description: Carry CWD-2943's improvements across to RFC 2307 directories.
fields.summary: Improve group synchronisation for RFC 2307 directories

fields.description:
Fetching the parent groups for a user in an RFC 2307 directory fails:

{noformat}
java.lang.ClassCastException: com.google.common.collect.Iterables$8 cannot be cast to java.util.List
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC2307Directory.searchGroupRelationshipsWithGroupTypeSpecified(RFC2307Directory.java:196)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchGroupRelationships(SpringLDAPConnector.java:1388)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.searchDirectGroupRelationships(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:889)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.searchNestedGroupRelationships(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:1069)
{noformat}

RFC2307Directory has been refactored to use {{Iterable}} for group relationship queries but one case still tries to cast to {{List}}.
fields.summary: Getting names of group memberships for a user in an RFC 2307 directories fails with ClassCastException

fields.description: With CWD-2470, users can provide the endpoint URL when logging in to sites with CrowdID. We should make it more visible, in the documentation or on the public identity page.
fields.summary: Make the OpenID endpoint URL more prominent

fields.description: CWD-3003 allowed OpenID realms to be approved automatically through a configuration file. That same functionality should be configurable through the user interface with the other Trust Relationships changes.
fields.summary: Allow configuring the automatic approval whitelist through the UI

fields.description: CrowdID's 'Trust Relationships' expects hostnames or IP addresses but allows entry of arbitrary strings. Entering URLs of RPs seems to work but will have no effect.
fields.summary: OpenID Trust Relationships should check for valid IP addresses

fields.description: The platform CTK validates an application's implementation of SAL on behalf of plugins. Get this running as part of Crowd's build to identify any bugs.
fields.summary: Run the Platform CTK in Crowd's tests

fields.description:
The Stash product added support for Crowd a while back, but continues to not have Crowd's SSO support.

Please communicate to the Stash team that having an Atlassian Enterprise-grade product (i.e. Stash) that doesn't log into Enterprise-grade features of other Atlassian products (i.e. Crowd) is frustrating and, dare I say, second-rate.  It essentially nullifies the SSO benefit for a portion of the Atlassian portfolio and makes it unclear how well Atlassian understands its own products.

Thanks for all the hard work, guys!
fields.summary: Evangelize Crowd SSO support to Stash team

fields.description:
The code that provides a direct upgrade path from very old, unsupported Crowd (< 2.0, released in July 2009) versions to the latest version makes direct use of now-unsupported classes and methods in Hibernate. If this code prevents an upgrade to Hibernate 4 then the cleanest option may be to remove it.

Customers upgrading from an earlier version would need to first install Crowd 2.[0-6] before upgrading to a later version.
fields.summary: Remove direct upgrade path from very old Crowd versions (<2.0)

fields.description:
Using a PluginSettingsFactory in a Crowd plugin fails on modification attempts:

{noformat}
org.springframework.dao.InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException: Write operations are not allowed in read-only mode (FlushMode.MANUAL): Turn your Session into FlushMode.COMMIT/AUTO or remove 'readOnly' marker from transaction definition.
	at org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateTemplate.checkWriteOperationAllowed(HibernateTemplate.java:1175)
	at org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateTemplate$16.doInHibernate(HibernateTemplate.java:739)
	at org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateTemplate.doExecute(HibernateTemplate.java:406)
	at org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateTemplate.executeWithNativeSession(HibernateTemplate.java:374)
	at org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateTemplate.saveOrUpdate(HibernateTemplate.java:737)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.util.persistence.hibernate.HibernateDao.update(HibernateDao.java:63)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.property.PropertyDAOHibernate.update(PropertyDAOHibernate.java:62)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.property.PluginPropertyManagerGeneric.setProperty(PluginPropertyManagerGeneric.java:64)
	at com.atlassian.sal.crowd.pluginsettings.CrowdPluginSettings.putActual(CrowdPluginSettings.java:54)
	at com.atlassian.sal.core.pluginsettings.AbstractStringPluginSettings.put(AbstractStringPluginSettings.java:76)
	at group.ExampleServlet.doGet(ExampleServlet.java:44)
{noformat}

The PluginPropertyManager needs an interceptor configured to set the appropriate transaction behaviour for that session.
fields.summary: PluginSettingsFactory does not create transactions

fields.description: Running into out of memory errors when trying to sync to a large directory, logs aren't very useful in informing you about why you're running into an error.
fields.summary: Better recovery when running out of memory
Show details of synchronisation failure in the user interface

fields.description: Upgrade third-party dependencies to pick up bug fixes.
fields.summary: Upgrade dependencies

fields.description: CWD-3104 removes the last use of TokenSeed. Remove it from the UI.
fields.summary: Remove TokenSeed now it's no longer used

fields.description: {{LdapSshaPasswordEncoder}} uses a site-wide salt value. This is enough to prevent cracking passwords with hashes from another instance, but random salt would improve resistance to a site-wide attempt at password cracking, as well as hiding cases of password collision between users.
fields.summary: Use a random salt for SSHA password encoding

fields.description: During authentication, Crowd looks a user up by User Name Attribute to confirm they're present and retrieve their DN. It then binds using the DN. It would be useful to have that DN available at DEBUG-level while investigating issues with authentication.
fields.summary: Log the DN used in an authentication bind at DEBUG
Connecting the five users

fields.description: Crowd still only sends out plain-text emails. User experience and look/feel can be improved and made consistent with rest of Atlassian apps' email notifications by supporting HTML emails.
fields.summary: Support for HTML emails sent by Crowd to users/admins

fields.description:
h1. Symptoms
Once a directory has been set to bind with a username/password, it is not possible to set it to anonymous bind.

h1. Steps to reproduce
# Set up an LDAP server that allows anonymous bind
# In Crowd, create a new connector, set an invalid username and password.
# Save the new connector. Test the connection. It should fail because of the invalid username and password.
# Go to Update connector to change its configuration.
# Clear the username field (the password field is already empty because the existing password is not revealed).
# Submit the form and test the connection again.

h1. Expected behaviour

The test should pass, because the directory is configured to use anonymous bind.

h1. Actual behaviour

The test fails, because the directory configuration still retains the old password.
fields.summary: Unable to change a connector to use anonymous bind

fields.description: Atlassian Core brings in a lot of dependencies but we only use a small number of its classes. Some of the classes from atlassian-core, such as EasyList, EasyMap or StringUtils, can be replaced by their Guava equivalents.
fields.summary: Replace atlassian-core with Guava where a straightforward replacement exists

fields.description:
h1. Symptoms
After a (failed) attempt to add a local group as a child of a remote group, the UI is left in an unusable state.
h1. Steps to reproduce
Same as CWD-3090.
h1. Expected behaviour
Crowd recovers gracefully from the failure and the UI remains functional.
h1. Actual behaviour
See attached screenshots, and also the stacktrace in the comments to CWD-3090.
fields.summary: Screen without data after failing to add a local group to a remote group

fields.description:
h4. Symptoms

When creating a new LDAP connector directory, it's impossible to save the directory without specifying the bind user "User DN" and "Password". Testing the connection with the anonymous credentials works fine.

This will show up as the following error messages in the interface:

# "The User DN cannot be blank for this directory." under "User DN"
# "Password cannot be blank." under "Password"

Neither of these fields are marked with an asterisk to indicate that they are mandatory.

h4. Steps to Reproduce

# Directories > Add Directory
# Connector
# Fill in all details, and leave "User DN" and "Password" empty in the "Connector" tab
# Try to save the directory

h4. Workaround

There are two possible workarounds:

# Use a username and password instead of anonymous access
# Use the latest version of Crowd that doesn't have this bug - 2.5.1
fields.summary: Can't create a new LDAP connector directory with anonymous bind user dn
Add default salt generation when a PropertyManager has not been injected in the ssha password encoder

fields.description:
Updating the copy due to negative feedback about the harsh warning of being locked out once Crowd exceeds the user limit.

Revised copy can be found: https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Update+Email+about+Exceeding+User+Limit
fields.summary: Update copy in exceeding user limit warning email to administrators

fields.description:
h1. Symptoms
Users deletions in an AD are not propagated to Crowd by (apparently successful) incremental synchronisation if the connector binds to AD using unprivileged credentials.
h1. Steps to reproduce
# Create an unprivileged user in AD, e.g., CN=UnprivUser,OU=People,DC=sydney,DC=atlassian,DC=com
# Set up an AD LDAP connector in Crowd, use the unprivileged user credentials to connect to AD.
# Do a full synchronisation
# Create a new ephemeral user in AD using the AD console or any other tool different from Crowd itself.
# Synchronise again. An incremental synchronisation successfully propagates the new user to Crowd. Verify the new user actually exists in Crowd with the user browser.
# Delete the ephemeral user from AD using the AD console or any other tool different from Crowd itself.
# Synchronise again.

h1. Expected behaviour
Either the deletion is propagated from AD to Crowd if possible (fallback to full sync?), or the user is notified about the failure to complete an incremental synchronisation (see CWD-2714).
h1. Actual behaviour
The deletion is not propagated from AD to Crowd. The synchronisation completes without any error message, logs contain "deleting [ 0 ] users", and the ephemeral user still appears in the user browser.
fields.summary: Incremental AD synchronisation silently ignores remote deletions if the user does not have admin privileges

fields.description:
When using a LDAP connector to synchronize a user directory, it is possible to have user account which do not have the email address. 

This will actually cause some problem for JIRA and Confluence as 
# The email address is a required information when creating user inside of JIRA. 
# Some feature like mention or user picker which is relied to the email address will not work correctly. 

We should add a warning message when the user is integrated Crowd with JIRA or Confluence for the user management to inform the potential problem with the user account without email address.
fields.summary: Adding warning message for the user account without email address

fields.description:
With CWD-1284, adding a remote group as a child of a local group fails without any feedback in the UI.

If this doesn't work then there should be a clear error message.
fields.summary: UpdateGroupMembers fails with no UI feedback

fields.description:
CWD-1284 allows groups to be managed locally. Local groups can contain remote users, but they can't contain remote groups.

We should relax this restriction if it's simple enough to do so.
fields.summary: Allow remote groups as children of local groups when managing groups locally in a syncing directory (Connector)

fields.description: DirectoryDAOFile logs when it loads a local {{directories.properties}} file but, when the file is deleted, doesn't log that it's going back to fetching definitions from the database.
fields.summary: DirectoryDAOFile should log when it is no longer using a local file

fields.description: ViewConnector and UpdateConnector fail with a NullPointerException when an unknown directory ID is passed. They should return a 404.
fields.summary: ViewConnector/UpdateConnector should return a 404 for missing directories

fields.description:
h1. Symptoms 
An org.springframework.ldap.UncategorizedLdapException exception is thrown when testing searching users/groups while setting up a new ActiveDirectory connector. The exception is uncaught, therefore the user is shown a blank screen, and an stacktrace appears in the logs.
h1. Steps to reproduce
# Click on 'Add directory'
# Select 'Connector'
# Enter a name
# Switch to the 2nd tab ('Connector')
# Pick 'Microsoft Active Directory'
# Enter a correct URL (e.g. ldap://crowd-ad1:389/), a correct base DN and correct credentials
# Optionally, click on 'Test connection'. The test should pass.
# Change to the 3rd tab ('Configuration').
# Click on 'Test search'.

Expected result: an error message is displayed on the screen to inform the user.

Actual result: blank screen, and stacktrace in the logs.
h1. Stacktrace
{code}

com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: org.springframework.ldap.UncategorizedLdapException: Uncategorized exception occured during LDAP processing; nested exception is javax.naming.NamingException: [LDAP: error code 1 - 00000000: LdapErr: DSID-0C090627, comment: In order to perform this operation a successful bind must be completed on the connection., data 0, vece]; remaining name 'dc=sydney,dc=atlassian,dc=com'
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.pageSearchResults(SpringLDAPConnector.java:385)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchEntitiesWithRequestControls(SpringLDAPConnector.java:418)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchEntities(SpringLDAPConnector.java:403)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchUserObjects(SpringLDAPConnector.java:592)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchUsers(SpringLDAPConnector.java:958)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.directory.LDAPConfigurationTester$Strategy$1.search(LDAPConfigurationTester.java:29)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.directory.LDAPConfigurationTesterImpl.canFindLdapObjects(LDAPConfigurationTesterImpl.java:27)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.directory.CreateConnector.doTestSearch(CreateConnector.java:238)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.directory.CreateConnector.doTestPrincipalSearch(CreateConnector.java:220)
...
Caused by: org.springframework.ldap.UncategorizedLdapException: Uncategorized exception occured during LDAP processing; nested exception is javax.naming.NamingException: [LDAP: error code 1 - 00000000: LdapErr: DSID-0C090627, comment: In order to perform this operation a successful bind must be completed on the connection., data 0, vece]; remaining name 'dc=sydney,dc=atlassian,dc=com'
	at org.springframework.ldap.support.LdapUtils.convertLdapException(LdapUtils.java:217)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate.search(LdapTemplate.java:319)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate.search(LdapTemplate.java:237)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper$4.call(LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper.java:92)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper$4.call(LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper.java:89)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper.invokeWithContextClassLoader(LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper.java:47)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper.search(LdapTemplateWithClassLoaderWrapper.java:89)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.pageSearchResults(SpringLDAPConnector.java:352)
	... 134 more
Caused by: javax.naming.NamingException: [LDAP: error code 1 - 00000000: LdapErr: DSID-0C090627, comment: In order to perform this operation a successful bind must be completed on the connection., data 0, vece]; remaining name 'dc=sydney,dc=atlassian,dc=com'
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtx.mapErrorCode(LdapCtx.java:3127)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtx.processReturnCode(LdapCtx.java:3033)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtx.processReturnCode(LdapCtx.java:2840)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtx.searchAux(LdapCtx.java:1849)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtx.c_search(LdapCtx.java:1772)
	at com.sun.jndi.toolkit.ctx.ComponentDirContext.p_search(ComponentDirContext.java:386)
	at com.sun.jndi.toolkit.ctx.PartialCompositeDirContext.search(PartialCompositeDirContext.java:356)

{code}
fields.summary: Uncaught exception when testing a connector

fields.description: {{TokenReaper}} runs a background sweep to delete any expired session tokens. However, it's wired up incorrectly and throws a {{NullPointerException}} rather than hitting the database. This is then wrapped as a {{JobExecutionException}} and logged at INFO by Quartz, which is below the default threshhold.
fields.summary: TokenReaper task does not delete expired tokens in the background

fields.description: Would be nice to have "Read Only with Local Groups" in Crowd Directory as the same we see in Confluence in order to add groups to the internal directory and add LDAP users to those groups.
fields.summary: Implement Read Only with Local Groups in Crowd Directory

fields.description: Copy the existing feature in Embedded Crowd.
fields.summary: As a Crowd user, I want a troubleshoot page to diagnose directory connection problems

fields.description:
Hi,

We had a 50-user crowd license, hooked up to our LDAP server, with only 22 users or so. We use Jira and Confluence, and they authenticate against Crowd. We also use the Crowd built-in account management to allow users to change their password.

We have one directory setup for Jira and Confluence to authenticate against. This is read-only to our LDAP server, so the Jira and Confluence groups don't propagate up to our LDAP server.

We have another directory setup for Crowd only, as write, so users can change their passwords.

So when a user changes their password, we found out they are counted twice, even though it's the same user in both directories. This posed a problem for us licence-wise, and locked us out of our account. We only need a 50-user license, and to pay the extra $1100 or so for a license we don't need, doesn't make sense.

Is there a way around this?
fields.summary: Don't count same user in multiple directories multiple times

fields.description: Openid4java 0.9.7 has been released [with a few fixes|https://groups.google.com/d/topic/openid4java/flHxpagPwnw/discussion]. Upgrade before making a major release.
fields.summary: Upgrade openid4java to 0.9.7
Redirect non-canonical OpenID URIs

fields.description:
While looking for instructions about setting up a new server using Apache + Crowd integration (for BUILDENG-2743) I found the page at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Installing+the+Crowd+Apache+Connector+on+Red+Hat+Enterprise+Linux which points to https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/svn/CWDAPACHE/tags/2.0.1/packages/PACKAGE_RELATIVE_URL which doesn't exist any more.

As far as I can tell, the current location is at https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/cwdapache, and perhaps it's worth also verifying that the instructions are still correct.
fields.summary: Apache Crowd connector instructions point to outdated link

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}

It's possible for search restrictions to end up as invalid HQL queries. For example:

{noformat}
<boolean-search-restriction boolean-logic='and'> <restrictions> <null-search-restriction/> <property-search-restriction> <property> <name>admin</name> <type>STRING</type> </property> <match-mode>EXACTLY_MATCHES</match-mode> <value>admin</value> </property-search-restriction> </restrictions> </boolean-search-restriction>
{noformat}

leads to an {{AND}} without anything on the left.
fields.summary: Search requests can generate invalid HQL queries

fields.description: CWD-3058 would have been caught earlier with a regression test that checked actual representations. We should capture input/output for 2.5 and treat any (unintended) changes from that as bugs.
fields.summary: Create a regression test suite for XML/JSON representations for REST API

fields.description:
h1. Steps to reproduce
# Create a LDAP connector directory with 'Local groups' enabled
# Create a local group
# Export an XML backup

There is no trace of the newly created group in the XML backup.
fields.summary: Local groups in connector directories are not imported/exported in XML backups

fields.description: OpenID requests are approved by realm. It's possible to specify an overly general realm (e.g. {{http://*.com/}}). It would be good to warn the user in this case.
fields.summary: Warn about overly general Realms in OpenID requests

fields.description: Some methods in RestCrowdClient declare UnsupportedCrowdApiException, which is documented to be thrown if the server does not support the appropriate version of the API. However, the exception is not actually thrown in this event, instead, an InvalidCrowdServiceException is thrown.
fields.summary: UnsupportedCrowdApiException is not actually thrown by RestCrowdClient when the REST API is missing

fields.description: The new OpenID endpoint only considers POST-ed indirect requests. This breaks interoperability with {{python-openid}}. Indirect requests should be allowed as GETs for {{checkid_immediate}} or {{checkid_setup}}.
fields.summary: Accept 'GET' requests to the OpenID endpoint

fields.description:
Occasionally Crowd's UI appears with all messages and labels blank. It looks like all i18n resources are being returned as empty strings.

Reproduced with Chrome and Safari.
fields.summary: Text-less pages in the Crowd console

fields.description: Add a feature to enable group aliases
fields.summary: Group Aliases

fields.description:
Crowd's initial setup could be improved to offer a better idea of progress, more feedback and more information about errors.

Errors often bubble up and are shown as warnings: more context-specific information would help, about what's gone wrong, the consequences and the steps to fix it.
fields.summary: Improve error reporting during setup

fields.description:
Crowd's OpenID approvals are based around the {{return_to}} URL. An OpenID 2 request may present a more general {{realm}} as well ([Realms|http://openid.net/specs/openid-authentication-2_0.html#realms]). If present, the user should be asked to approve the realm for this and future requests.

If a whitelist is present (CWD-3045) it should be treated as a list of realms. Any realm must either be directly present on the whitelist (if it's a pattern) or match something on the whitelist if it's a concrete return_to URL.
fields.summary: Use OpenID Realm for approval requests
SearchResource JSON format has changed

fields.description: Since CWD-2876, there is a REST operation to invalidate all sessions of a given user (possibly saving one session). New methods should be added to RestCrowdClient to make use of this new operation.
fields.summary: Add an operation in the REST client to invalidate all tokens of a given user

fields.description: I would like to add Users to Crowd/Jira directly from LDAP (as in Contour) without having the users attempting to sign in to any crowd affiliated tool. I don't want users to just sign in without an administrator setting up his/her permissions either because we have security groups.
fields.summary: Add Users to Crowd/JIRA directly from LDAP

fields.description: Any Crowd configuration files that are monitored for changes are currently polled. Taking advantage of JDK 7's file change notification would mean changes were picked up more quickly.
fields.summary: Use file change notification for configuration files

fields.description:
Oracle's JDK 6 will [soon end public updates|http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/eol-135779.html]:

bq. After February 2013, Oracle will no longer post updates of Java SE 6 to its public download sites.

Crowd should drop support to focus on JDK 7 and start taking advantage of Java 7 features.
fields.summary: Require Java 7

fields.description: Crowd's REST resources are application-specific views of the users and groups, with directories abstracted away. This causes problems (CWD-2119) and means functionality is missing (CWD-3047). Crowd should have a full set of resources that distinguish directories, like the web user interface.
fields.summary: Expose user directories as REST resources

fields.description:
When Crowd issues a SQL query to expire old tokens (older than a certain reference timestamp), it is truncating the timestamp to a date, i.e., it ignores hours, minutes, seconds.

This is the query as seen in the PostgreSQL logs:

{code}
delete from cwd_token where last_accessed_date<$1

with parameter $1='2013-01-08 00:00:00'
{code}

Consequently, tokens that should be expired are not being expired if the default session duration is in the range of hours or less.
fields.summary: The SQL query to expire old tokens truncates the date

fields.description:
h3. Steps to replicate
# Configure JIRA to use CROWD user directory and then synchronize
# Enable the [alias feature|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Specifying+a+User%27s+Aliases] in Crowd and add an alias to a user
# In JIRA, synchronise Crowd directory again
# Login to JIRA with the username (not the alias user)

When viewing the list of users in JIRA, it will display both the username and the alias, thus create two accounts for a single user

h3. Workaround:
Re-create the Crowd Directory again.  For example, remove the Crowd directory in JIRA and then re-configure the Crowd User Directory.  Lastly, synchronise JIRA with the Crowd directory.
fields.summary: Crowd's alias creates multiple accounts

fields.description:
Using REST API, it's possible for us to authenticate to Crowd by using a Crowd application credentials, and perform some operations such as retrieving user/group information, etc. 

Specifically when creating a group in Crowd, we are given the option to specify the directory which we want to create a group in. But when using REST API, apparently we are unable to specify which directory we should the created group belongs to, and upon creating a group via REST, the group will be added to all of the directories associated to the application. 

A sample REST request to create a group in Crowd:
{code}
curl -D- -u jira:admin -X POST --data @/Users/BaBs/Desktop/group.json -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://afaisal-pc:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/group
{code}

Sample of the JSON data:
{code}
{
   "name" : "MyGroup",
   "type" : "GROUP",
   "description" : "MyDescription",
   "active" : true
}
{code}

Output when executing the above REST POST request:
- The group will appear in My Crowd directory:
!My Crowd.png!
- The group will also get created in My OpenDS directory:
!My OpenDS.png!
(i) note that both My Crowd and My OpenDS directory are mapped to the {{jira}} application

Hence, it will be great if we are able to specify the directory ID when creating a group as well, so that the group will specifically be created under the specified directory
fields.summary: Add the ability to specify the directory when creating a group via REST API

fields.description:
When adding the user on Crowd, first we set the username and email, password, and so on. After that, we set the group.
Before setting the group, the user is synchronised to the JIRA user depending on the timing.

In this case, there is the following issue.
If setting the alias to the user on Crowd, though the user is same, the another user is added to the JIRA user.

steps
1. select 'User' -> 'User Directory' -> 'Edit' on JIRA
2. set 'Synchronisation Interval' to 1 minuite
3. 'Add User' on Crowd
4. push 'Create' button
5. (Please wait a moment)On this timing, the user is syschronised to the JIRA user.
6. set the alias to the user on the Applications tab of Crowd 
7. see the JIRA User, then the another user is added

We think the user should be saved after setting the group on Crowd.
fields.summary: The user which has no group is created as the JIRA user.

fields.description: To simplify use of OpenID 2 to authenticate known third-party sites, allow a list of sites to be specified administratively that will automatically be approved without user action.
fields.summary: Allow a whitelist of automatically-approved sites for CrowdID

fields.description:
Its looks like it is crowd embedded that actually does this. It looks like the logging is proportional to the number of groups. We don't need this much detail in the logs it will blow their size out of large LDAP directories. Admins of JIRA really don't care about these details. If they need to DEBUG performance problems then they should enable debugging rather than having it on by default. We should

# Get Crowd Embedded to drop these messages to DEBUG.

We can (should?) keep around the "synchronisation" started and "synchronisation" finished logs when we fix this.

For example, here is a sync with a small directory of ~ 10 users and ~ 5 groups.

{noformat}

fields.summary: Reduce logging during directory synchronization

fields.description:
affects 2.6.0-m2

FilteredCrowdServiceImpl gets unfiltered results from its parent implementation, which will return at most maxQuery results. It then removes filtered groups from the results, and returns fewer than maxResults groups, even though more are available.

Note that the start index also needs to be modified -- increased by the number of filtered groups which appear before that point.

The ideal solution might be to AND the filteredGroups set with the query passed in and let the parent class do the work.
fields.summary: FilteredCrowdServiceImpl returns too few Group results when filteredGroups is not empty

fields.description: Since CWD-3028, this column has been replaced by last_accessed_time. It can be removed from the schema.
fields.summary: Drop column cwd_token.last_accessed_date, which is no longer in use

fields.description:
Crowd's HTML has a number of issues that could be cleaned up.

* Declare pages as HTML5
* Move script function definitions to top of page (setHelpLink)
* Check if script@language is necessary in supported browsers
* No such thing as 'content' element
* No such thing as 'tag' attribute
* Incorrect use of {{<input size='35px'>}}
* Use {{<meta charset=}} consistently
fields.summary: Clean up HTML in the web interface

fields.description: Remove the extra 's' so the spelling doesn't get propagated into acceptance tests.
fields.summary: Fix spelling of CSS class 'successsBox'.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 
h3. Steps to Rerproduce
# Create a FedoraDS/389-DS directory
# Create some users and groups (be sure to enable posix for all)
# Assign a GID (group id) to each user to assign their primary group
# Add multiple users as members of multiple groups
# Connect to Crowd (as FedoraDS type directory) and synchronise
# Observe that only the primary group memberships exist and the other memberships do not

h3. Workaround
Set up the directory as a Generic Directory Server, with all the same properties, and the memberships will work correctly.

h3. Cause
FedoraDS/389-DS data is expecting the uniqueMember value to be populated with DNs, which is the RFC 4519 behaviour. Crowd will not pick that up if it's been configured as 'FedoraDS', despite this being the default for this directory type.
fields.summary: Using FedoraDS or 389-DS only one group membership exists per user

fields.description: CWD-2943 improved synchronisation for OpenLDAP but not for the first, full sync of a remote Active Directory. Ensure the same improvements are made.
fields.summary: Improve Active Directory full synchronisation of memberships
Produce directory configuration files from the current database-based directory configuration
Create an acceptance test suite for Crowd running with a file-based directory configuration

fields.description: If a directory update operation fails for some reason (different from DirectoryNotFoundException), a stacktrace appears on screen.
fields.summary: Stacktrace is displayed if updating a directory fails

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 18th March 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi,

I wanted to let you know that we have released new easy to configure & cross-domain Single Sign-On in [Crowd Data Center 3.4|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-3-4-release-notes-966041084.html] 

You can download Crowd Data Center from here: https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download/data-center

Please note that in order to use cross-domain Single Sign-On in Crowd you will need Crowd Data Center license.

You can create your evaluation license for Crowd Data Center here https://my.atlassian.com/license/evaluation

If you need any assistance with the Crowd Data Center installation you can follow our Getting started guide https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/installing-crowd-data-center-935369773.html

We hope that you will enjoy it as much as we do!

Please reply directly to my email to share your feedback or just add your comments in this ticket. We'd love to hear your thoughts!

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
Senior Product Manager, Crowd
mradochonski@atlassian.com
 
{panel}

Crowd should have better ways to use the information in the database regarding SSO without having to modify any 
files(crowd.properties, seraph-config.xml) within Atlassian Products.
fields.summary: Crowd should support seamless SSO integration

fields.description: Applications may need more than one token per user, for instance, to temporarily grant elevated privileges to a user. In order to verify that the token presented by a user actually corresponds to the privilege level that the application requires for an operation, a new validation factor is required.
fields.summary: Add a new validation factor to distinguish between tokens with different privileges

fields.description: As an application, I want to create a token for user that is valid for a short period of time. For instance, to temporarily grant the user access to a restricted part of the application.
fields.summary: As an application, I want to create short-lived tokens

fields.description: Make sure the Spring Security integration performance does not suffer from the switch from SOAP to REST. There are some cache classes (com.atlassian.crowd.service.cache.CachingUserManager, CachingGroupMembershipManager and CachingGroupManager) that are coupled to the SOAP API and may need to be adapted or replaced when the implementation moves to REST.
fields.summary: Add cache to the portion of the REST API client that is used by the Spring Security integration

fields.description: Spring Security integration is currently being functionally tested by means of its usage in the Crowd app. However, as the latter is adopting some specific behaviour (CWD-2995), it becomes a less useful test subject. A new suite that exercises the "vanilla" Spring Security Integration is required.
fields.summary: Create acceptance tests to exercise the Spring Security integration

fields.description:
An LDAP directory supports 2 modes:

* *Read Only*
Users, groups and memberships are retrieved from your LDAP server and cannot be modified in the application.
* *Read Only, with Local Groups*
Users, groups and memberships are retrieved from your LDAP server and cannot be modified. Users from LDAP can be added to groups maintained in the application's internal directory.


For a Crowd based directory only the "Read Only" mode is currently available but it would be beneficial to support the "Read Only, with Local Groups: for Crowd as well.
fields.summary: Allow local groups to be associated with users synced from Crowd

fields.description: Crowd currently depends on dom4j 1.4, which is known to have some bugs (see CWD-3022) and it's more than 8 years old. We should upgrade to a more recent version to avoid being bitten by these bugs again.
fields.summary: Upgrade to dom4j 1.6

fields.description: When a backup is restored from an XML file, Crowd parses the file using platform-dependent encoding, regardless of the declaration in the XML header. This causes problems when importing backup files (which are usually in UTF-8) in Crowd instances that are running in a non-UTF-8 system, such as a Mac.
fields.summary: Crowd uses platform-dependent encoding to parse XML file when importing a backup

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Users is some cases need to add some additional fields to be filled when adding a new user from the UI.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be nice to add new fields in Crowd, like company, title, and phone number.
fields.summary: New fields in User Profile

fields.description:
Crowd does not provide the ability to mapped LDAP users with local membership for connector directory type. This feature has been implemented for Confluence and JIRA.

Hence when customer would like to migrate from Confluence or JIRA user management to Crowd, they will have an issue importing their users and groups as the only method to use local membership with LDAP users is only trough *DELEGATION*.
fields.summary: Allow Connector Directory to Mapped LDAP user with Local Membership

fields.description:
h3. Symptoms

When adding a new user to a directory with an LDAP connector, if you specify the user's active flag to false, it will still be created with active flag true. After adding the user, the flag can be turned off without issue.

This affects the Crowd Admin Console user interface, and also the REST API.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

In the admin console, add a user and set the active flag to "false". After the user is added, the active flag is set to true.

To replicate in REST:

{code:none}
curl -i -u test:test --data '{ "name" : "my_username", "first-name" : "My", "last-name" : "Username", "display-name" : "My Username", "email" : "user@example.test", "password" : { "value" : "my_password" }, "active" : false }' http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'Accept: application/json'
{code}

When this command is run, the user is created with the active flag set to "true" despite "false" being the value in the request payload.

This issue does *not* affect Crowd internal directories.

h3. Workaround

Manually set the flag after the create command, or send a REST command to update the flag.
fields.summary: When adding a user to an LDAP connector directory, "active" flag is ignored

fields.description: CWD-2420 means that {{remote_address_binary}} and {{remote_address_mask}} are redundant in the {{cwd_application_address}} table. They should be removed from new databases, and possibly dropped from old ones.
fields.summary: Remove unused remote_address_binary and remote_address_mask columns

fields.description:
As an application integrator, I would like to map multiple Crowd group names to my application role names.

With the Spring integration in Crowd 2.5, there are two mechanisms to grant Spring authority roles to users:

# Transforming each membership into a role, which names are optionally prepended with a prefix (e.g., ROLE_crowd_administrators).
# Granting a single authority (e.g., ROLE_ADMIN) to every user which membership intersects with the groups that are granted access to the application.

Therefore, it is not possible to have multiple roles AND fully configurable names at the same time. For instance, if my application uses authorities ROLE_ADMIN and ROLE_USER, I need the groups to be named ADMIN and USER in Crowd, because I can only prepend them with a prefix.
fields.summary: Add support for configurable mapping of group names to role names

fields.description: An application may want to know which groups have been granted access to it.
fields.summary: Add a REST API to get the list of authorised groups per application

fields.description:
We have had multiple requersts and issues around the usage of the Crowd Client libraries in other OpenSource products and also in other commercial products.

Since the Crowd Client libraries are useless without a Crowd Server (something which a customer would pay for), there is really no issue in allowing the distribution of the client libraries in third party products. It is a selling point for that third party product and a revenue stream for Atlassian, if that third party customer:
# Buys Crowd because they want SSO
# They are already an Atlassian customer

I would suggest that not only should the Crowd REST client be made open source but also the Spring Security integration.
fields.summary: Move the Crowd Integration libraries to be Open Source

fields.description: We're using the Crowd token as a remember me token and we want to cycle them daily. In order to do this we need Crowd to return the token creation date in the response of the /session/{token} POST response.
fields.summary: Return the token creation date in the /session/{token} POST response

fields.description:
Email Address of the user created in AD with email list , when verifying in CROWD email address to this user is blank.

e.g.. user name : developer associated mail id : developer@xyz.com and many emails in this email id.

When verified in CROWD , this user 'developer' email address is blank.
fields.summary: Email address of user created(in AD) with email list is not available when verifying in crowd

fields.description: To avoid database index degradation on Postgres combined with a clustered Crowd environment we would like to have token management implemented via a distributed memory store.
fields.summary: Token management in distributed memory store

fields.description:
We would like the ability to configure Crowd to deal with a cluster of LDAP instances. Current thinking was to have one write LDAP server and multiple read only servers.  Currently Crowd stores directory config in the database which makes it difficult to specify different LDAP instances. 

The option currently considered is to provide one read only LDAP per instance of Crowd. This would require the ability to externalise the directory config.
fields.summary: Externalise directory configuration from the database

fields.description:
We currently have a requirement to supply WebSudo capability to applications that we are protecting with Crowd i.e the ability to re-authenticate for admin functions. 

I was thinking that we may be able to leverage Crowd to provide this capability.
fields.summary: Support for WebSudo

fields.description:
If you call the /session REST service to create a new session token the username that gets returned in the response has the same case as the username that was passed through, e.g.

Username as appears in the directory:
test@example.com

Call the /session service:
{code}
<authentication-context>
  <username>tEst@EXAMPLE.com</username>
  <password>password</password>
</authentication-context>
{code}

Response:
{code}
<session expand="user">
    <token>0fX2yGuAWNdhuaMawedehQ00</token>
    <user name="tEst@EXAMPLE.com">        
        <link rel="self" href="http://idm-access-staging.private.atlassian.com:8081/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user?username=tEst@EXAMPLE.com" />
    </user>
    <link rel="self" href="http://idm-access-staging.private.atlassian.com:8081/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/session/0fX2yGuAWNdhuaMawedehQ00" />
</session>
{code}

The response should have returned the username in the original case (test@example.com) like the other Crowd REST services. It should also follow the "Lower Case Output" option set on the application calling the REST service.
fields.summary: Username returned in the /session REST services has incorrect casing

fields.description:
Currently when a Crowd token is rejected it will only show up in the log file if the log level is set to DEBUG. We don't usually run Crowd in DEBUG mode in a production environment so this causes issues when trying to investigate issues with Crowd tokens. It would be useful if there was a one line message that contained:

* the token and any validation factors,
* the user the token belongs to,
* and the reason it was rejected
fields.summary: Log a message when Crowd Tokens do not validate/are rejected

fields.description: The crowd-test runner brings up the app with latin encoding. It should bring up the app with the expected tomcat config with UTF-8 for both URI Encoding and useBodyEncodingForURI.
fields.summary: Update crowd test runner to bring up the app with proper encoding

fields.description: Many of Crowd's pages claim to be XHTML strict; they're not. Some more claim to be HTML Transitional. For consistency, make everything "!DOCTYPE html".
fields.summary: Declare all pages as HTML 5

fields.description:
The page footer does not stay attached to the bottom of the window when creating delegated authentication directories.

Also, the 'permissions' tab appears empty.
fields.summary: Broken markup for creating delegated authentication directories
